comments.body: I would suggest to not have a description here until this is a bit better documented (iirc the current docs still don’t tell me how to actually invoke it) so it doesn’t show up in `--help`. If we do really want for it to show up in `--help` we should at least add `(experimental)` like we do for other commands.
The docs for TypeScript will tomorrow. The existing desc. has been there since time immemorial. Are you sure you want me to hide it?
Ah I forgot that this is also the codegen for Java and Scala. In that case, let’s keep it.
K, k.

diffHunk:
@@ -50,6 +50,12 @@ commands:
   path: daml-helper/daml-helper
   desc: "Interact with a DAML ledger (experimental)"
   args: ["ledger"]
+- name: codegen
+  path: daml-helper/daml-helper
+  desc: "Run a language bindings code generation tool"

comments.body: Why do we need this? Two commands that do exactly the same thing mainly seems confusing.

Is there a better way to do it? The first needs to exist in order that scala, java can be disambiguated from typescript. The second exists because it is called from `Run.hs` (the invocation of `daml2ts` needs to run in a DAML env). Note the second is "hidden".
You should be calling the `daml2ts` binary directly from `runDaml2ts` instead of invoking the assistant again.

This is the connection (`Run.hs`):
```haskell
runDaml2ts :: [String] -> IO ()
runDaml2ts remainingArgs = do
    -- Call back to the assistant because this needs to run in a DAML
    -- env.
    procConfig <- toAssistantCommand $ ["daml2ts"] ++ remainingArgs
    runProcess_ procConfig
```
(called from `Main.hs`).
You can get the location of the actual binary with something like `fmap (</> "daml2ts" </> "daml2ts") getSdkPath`.

> You should be calling the `daml2ts` binary directly from `runDaml2ts` instead of invoking the assistant again.

Should I? Can you help out with an example of how (respecting that it needs to run in the DAML env)? I really thought I was doing this as it was designed to be used and my meeting with @associahedron  seemed to confirm that (or at least he didn't tell me it was wrong).
See above for how you can get the path to the binary and then just run that. I don’t think adding hidden commands makes any sense so that you can proxy back through the assistant makes sense.
Thanks for the help. All fixed!

comments.body: LGTM, but we should pass the same argument when running this from `daml-helper` (in `daml start`). Happy to do this in a separate PR though.

diffHunk:
@@ -37,15 +37,15 @@ commands:
 - name: sandbox

   desc: "Launch the Sandbox"
-  args: ["run-jar", "daml-sdk/daml-sdk.jar", "sandbox"]
+  args: ["run-jar", "--logback-config=daml-sdk/sandbox-logback.xml", "daml-sdk/daml-sdk.jar", "sandbox"]

comments.body:
I don't think these should both be top level commands. Either we have:

* `daml party` with subcommands `daml party list` and `daml party allocate`, or
* these are all subcommands of `daml deploy`, as is the original `daml deploy` (could be `daml deploy package`, `daml deploy party`, `daml deploy party --list`, or so).

I'm partial to the latter (i.e. having all of these be subcommands of `daml deploy`), since the thing all of these commands have in common is that they need to communicate with a ledger on a given host/port.
I'm open to the idea of structured commands. Is there any prior art for this in `daml` ?

`da` used to have a bunch of them, and `daml install` sort of simulates this (with `daml install latest` / `daml install project` / `daml install VERSION`) but doesn't really do it the proper way, which is by using `subparser` and `command` in optparse-applicative.
I  think we can leave this restructuring to a later PR. It will be nice to get more opinions form the produce people.
